We wanted to take time to answer a few last minute questions that have been asked on social media this evening. We hope this "First Day FYI" helps our families get off to a great start tomorrow!

1) All schools will have normal hours of operation, 8 a.m. to 3 p.m.

2) Please expect for car lines to be longer than usual, as everyone gets in the routine of pick-up & drop-off. This happens at the beginning of every year, but there will be more car riders this year & more traffic. Delays are likely & parents should plan accordingly.

3) Breakfast will be served at all campuses. It is FREE to ALL students year-round.

See you tomorrow! #PointersPressOn

The Van Buren School District is keeping kids connected during this school closure with the help of some handy Wi-Fi devices! 📱💻 VBSD's Technology Department is installing access points to provide filtered internet capabilities. Chromebooks distributed by VBSD will automatically log in at each campus. Personal devices will require a teacher or student ID for access. Students who do not know their internet ID can contact their teacher or school to obtain one.

Families can utilize the free Wi-fi safely and conveniently from their vehicle in the school parking lot. Installations have been completed at Van Buren High School and the three grab-and-go meal sites, Central and Tate Elementary Schools, and Northridge Middle School. Work is currently in progress at Butterfield Trail Middle School and the Freshman Academy. The remaining campuses will be equipped with access points next week. Thank you to our amazing Technology Department for providing our families with these helpful tools! 👏👏👏 #PointerPride #PointerProfessionals

post_text: Please be aware there is NOT a proposed change in the millage rate for Van Buren. The item appearing on the ballot is simply procedural and required by law. According to Article 14 section 3 of the Arkansas Constitution, millage rates are required to be on the ballot at least once per year (Annual Ad Valorem) in every Arkansas school district, regardless of whether a district is seeking any change in its rate. If a district is seeking no change in its tax rate, as is the case with VBSD, the millage rate on the ballot is a reflection of the existing tax rate. The previous year millage rate always takes precedence regardless of the outcome of the vote.
